original_prompt: In this task, you will be shown a conversation and a question. You should categorize the question into matching, summary, logic, arithmetic and, commonsense groups. Matching is a question entailed or paraphrased by exactly one sentence in a dialogue. The answer can be extracted from the same sentence. Questions that cannot be answered by the surface meaning of a single sentence belong to the reasoning category. We further define summary, logic, arithmetic and, commonsense subcategories. Answering summary questions requires the whole picture of dialogue, such as the topic of dialogue and the relation between speakers. We require logical reasoning to answer logical questions. in arithmetic questions Inferring the answer requires arithmetic knowledge. To answer commonsense questions, besides the textual information in the dialogue, we also require additional commonsense knowledge that cannot be obtained from the dialogue. Note that a question can be in more than one group. "W" and "M" in the conversations stand for "woman" and "man".
generated_prompts: This task will provide you with a conversation and a question, and you are expected to categorize the question into matching, summary, logic, arithmetic and commonsense groups. Matching questions can be answered by extracting the answer from a single sentence in the dialogue. Questions that cannot be answered by the surface meaning of a single sentence are categorized as reasoning questions, which further divided into summary, logic, arithmetic and commonsense subcategories. Summary questions require the whole picture of the dialogue, such as the topic of dialogue and the relation between speakers, while logic questions require logical reasoning to answer. Arithmetic questions require inferring the answer with arithmetic knowledge, and commonsense questions require additional commonsense knowledge that cannot be obtained from the dialogue. Additionally, a question can belong to more than one group. In the conversation, "W" and "M" stands for "woman" and "man".

In this task, you will be shown a conversation and a question. You must categorize the question into one or more of the following groups: matching, summary, logic, arithmetic, and commonsense. Matching questions are entailed or paraphrased by exactly one sentence in the dialogue and the answer can be extracted from that sentence. Summary questions require understanding the whole conversation, such as the topic of the dialogue and the relation between the speakers. Logic questions require logical reasoning. Arithmetic questions require knowledge of arithmetic. Commonsense questions require knowledge beyond the conversation itself. The conversations will feature "W" and "M" which stand for "woman" and "man".

In this task, you will be given a conversation and a question. You are required to categorize the question into one or more of the following groups: matching, summary, logic, arithmetic and commonsense. Matching questions can be answered with a single sentence from the dialogue, whereas questions in the other categories require more knowledge. Summary questions require a general understanding of the dialogue, such as the topic and the relation between speakers. Logical questions require logical reasoning. Arithmetic questions involve arithmetic knowledge. Commonsense questions require additional knowledge that cannot be obtained from the dialogue. The conversation is composed of two speakers, identified as "W" and "M", which stand for "woman" and "man".

This task requires you to categorize a given question into one of the five groups: matching, summary, logic, arithmetic, and commonsense. Matching questions can be answered by a single sentence in the conversation, while summary, logic, arithmetic and commonsense questions require more context and knowledge. For summary questions, you need to know the whole conversation, not just one sentence. For logic questions, you need logical reasoning. For arithmetic questions, you need arithmetic knowledge. For commonsense questions, you need additional knowledge beyond the conversation. The conversation will use the abbreviations "W" and "M" for "woman" and "man". The question may fit into more than one group.
